revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
In [[Social psychology (psychology)|social psychology]], '''social value orientation''' ('''SVO''') is a person's preference about how to allocate resources (e.g. money) between the self and another person. SVO corresponds to how much weight a person attaches to the welfare of others in relation to the own. Since people are assumed to vary in the weight they attach to other peoples' outcomes in relation to their own, SVO is an [[Differential psychology|individual difference]] variable. The general concept underlying SVO has become widely studied in a variety of different scientific disciplines, such as [[economics]], [[sociology]], and [[biology]] under a multitude of different names (e.g. ''[[social preferences]]'', ''other-regarding preferences'', ''welfare tradeoff ratios'', ''social motives'', etc.).
==Historical background== The SVO construct has its history in the study of interdependent decision making, i.e. strategic interactions between two or more people. The advent of [[Game theory]] in the 1940s provided a formal language for describing and analyzing situations of interdependence based on [[utility theory]]. As a simplifying assumption for analyzing strategic interactions, it was generally presumed that people only consider their own outcomes when making decisions in interdependent situations, rather than taking into account the interaction partners' outcomes as well. However, the study of human behavior in [[social dilemma]] situations, such as the [[Prisoner's dilemma]], revealed that some people do in fact appear to have concerns for others.
In the [[Prisoner's dilemma]], participants are asked to take the role of two criminals. In this situation, they are to pretend that they are a pair of criminals being interrogated by detectives in separate rooms. Both participants are being offered a deal and have two options. That is, the participant may remain silent or confess and implicate his or her partner. However, if both participants choose to remain silent, they will be set free. If both participants confess they will receive a moderate sentence. Conversely, if one participant remains silent while the other confesses, the person who confesses will receive a minimal sentence while the person who remained silent (and was implicated by their partner) will receive a maximum sentence. Thus, participants have to make the decision to cooperate with or compete with their partner.
When used in the lab, the dynamics of this situation are stimulated as participants play for points or for money. Participants are given one of two choices, labeled option C or D. Option C would be the cooperative choice and if both participants choose to be cooperative then they will both earn points or money. On the other hand, Option D is the competitive choice. If just one participants chooses option D, that participant will earn points or money while the other player will lose money. However, if both participant pick D, then both of them will lose money. In addition to displaying participant's '''social value orientations''', it also displays the dynamics of a mixed-motives situation.<ref>Forsyth, D.R. (2006). Conflict. In Forsyth, D. R., Group Dynamics (5th Ed.) (P. 378-407) Belmont: CA, Wadsworth, Cengage Learning</ref>
From behavior in strategic situations it is not possible, though, to infer peoples' motives, i.e. the joint outcome they would choose if they alone could determine it. The reason is that behavior in a strategic situation is always a function of both peoples' preferences about joint outcomes ''and'' their beliefs about the intentions and behavior of their interaction partners.
In an attempt to assess peoples' preferences over joint outcomes alone, disentangled from their beliefs about the other persons' behavior, David M. Messick and Charles G. McClintock in 1968<ref name="Messick68">{{Cite journal| title = Motivational Bases of Choice in Experimental Games | last = Messick| first = D. M. |author2=McClintock, C. G. | year = 1968 | journal = Journal of Experimental Social Psychology | pages = 1–25 | volume = 4 | doi = 10.1016/0022-1031(68)90046-2}}</ref> devised what has become known as the ''decomposed game technique''. Basically, any task where one decision maker can alone determine which one out of at least two own-other resource allocation options will be realized is a ''decomposed game'' (also often referred to as [[dictator game]], especially in [[economics]], where it is often implemented as a constant-sum situation).
By observing which own-other resource allocation a person chooses in a ''decomposed game'', it is possible to infer that person's preferences over own-other resource allocations, i.e. ''social value orientation''. Since there is no other person making a decision that affects the joint outcome, there is no interdependence, and therefore a potential effect of beliefs on behavior is ruled out.
To give an example, consider two options, A and B. If you choose option A, you will receive $100, and another (unknown) person will receive $10. If you choose option B, you will receive $85, and the other (unknown) person will also receive $85. This is a ''decomposed game''. If a person chooses option B, we can infer that this person does not only consider the outcome for the self when making a decision, but also takes into account the outcome for the other.
==Conceptualization== When people seek to maximize their gains, they are said to be '''proself'''. But when people are also concerned with other's gains and losses, they are said to be '''prosocial'''. There are four categories within SVO. Individualistic and competitive SVOs are proself while cooperative and altruistic SVOs are prosocial:<ref>Forsyth, D.R. (2006). Conflict. In Forsyth, D. R., Group Dynamics (5th Ed.) (P. 378-407) Belmont: CA, Wadsworth, Cengage Learning</ref>
*'''Individualistic orientation''': Members of this category are concerned only with their own outcomes. They make decisions based on what they think they will personally achieve, without concern for others outcomes. They are focused only on their own outcomes and therefore do not get involved with other group members. they neither assist nor interfere. However their actions may indirectly impact other members of the group but such impact is not their goal. *'''Competitive orientation''': Competitors much like individualists strive to maximize their own outcomes, but in addition they seek to minimize others outcomes. disagreements and arguments are viewed as win-lose situations and competitors find satisfaction in forcing their ideas upon others. A competitor has the belief that each person should get the most they can in each situation and play to win every time. Those with competitive SVOs are more likely to find themselves in conflicts.<ref>Forsyth, D.R. (2006). Conflict. In Forsyth, D. R., Group Dynamics (5th Ed.) (P. 378-407) Belmont: CA, Wadsworth, Cengage Learning</ref> Competitors cause cooperators to react with criticism to their abrasive styles. However, competitors rarely modify their behavior in response to these complaints because they are relatively unconcerned with maintaining interpersonal relations. *'''Cooperative orientation''': Cooperators tend to maximize their own outcomes as well as other's outcomes. They prefer strategies that generate win-win situations. When dealing with other people they believe that it is better if everyone comes out even in a situation. *'''Altruistic orientation''': altruists are motivated to help other who are in need. Members of this category are low in self-interest. They willingly sacrifice their own outcomes in the hopes of helping others achieve gain.
However, in 1973 Griesinger and Livingston <ref name="Living73">{{Cite journal| title = Toward a model of interpersonal motivation in experimental games | last = Griesinger |first = D. W. |author2=Livingston, J. W. | year = 1973 | journal = Behavioral Science | pages = 173–188 | volume = 18 | doi = 10.1002/bs.3830180305| issue = 3}}</ref> provided a geometric framework of SVO (the ''SVO ring'', see ''Figure 1'') with which they could show that SVO is in principle not a categorical, but a continuous construct that allows for an infinite number of social value orientations.
[[File:SVO Ring.pdf|thumb|''Figure 1'': The SVO ring <ref name="Living73"/><ref name="Liebrand84"/>]]
The basic idea was to represent outcomes for the self (on the ''x-axis'') and for the other (on the ''y-axis'') on a [[Cartesian plane]], and represent own-other payoff allocation options as coordinates on a circle centered at the origin of the plane. If a person chooses a particular own-other outcome allocation on the ring, that person's SVO can be represented by the [[angle]] of the line starting at the origin of the Cartesian plane and intersecting the coordinates of the respective chosen own-other outcome allocation.
If, for instance, a person would choose the option on the circle that maximizes the own outcome, this would refer to an ''SVO angle'' of <math>0^{\circ}</math>, indicating a perfectly individualistic SVO. An angle of <math>45^{\circ}</math> would indicate a perfectly cooperative (maximizing joint outcomes) SVO, while an angle of <math>-45^{\circ}</math> would indicate a perfectly competitive (maximizing relative gain) SVO. This conceptualization indicates that SVO is a continuous construct, since there is an infinite number of possible SVOs, because angular degrees are [[Continuous function|continuous]].
This advancement in the conceptualization of the SVO construct also clarified that SVO as originally conceptualized can be represented in terms of a [[utility function]] of the following form
<math> U_{(\pi_{s}, \pi_{o})} = a*\pi_{s} + b*\pi_{o}</math>,
where <math>\pi_{s}</math> is the outcome for the self, <math>\pi_{o}</math> is the outcome for the other, and the parameters indicate the weight a person attaches to the own outcome (<math>a</math>) and the outcome for the other (<math>b</math>).
==Measurement== Several different measurement methods exist for assessing SVO.<ref name="AuKwong2004">{{cite book|title=Contemporary psychological research on social dilemmas|year=2004|publisher=New York: Cambridge University Press|author=Au, W.T.|author2=Kwong, J.Y.Y. |editor=Suleiman, R. |editor2=Budescu, D. |editor3=Fischer, I. |editor4=Messick, D.|pages=71–98|chapter=Measurement and effects of social-value orientation in social dilemmas}}</ref> The basis for any of these measures is the ''decomposed game technique'', i.e. a set of non-constant-sum [[dictator game]]s. The most commonly used SVO measures are the following.
===Ring Measure=== The Ring measure was devised by Wim B. G. Liebrand in 1984<ref name="Liebrand84">{{Cite journal| title = 'The effect of social motives, communication and group size on behaviour in an n-person multi stage mixed motive game | last = Liebrand |first = W. B. G. | year = 1984 | journal = European Journal of Social Psychology | pages = 239–264| volume = 14 | doi = 10.1002/ejsp.2420140302| issue = 3}}</ref> and is based on the geometric SVO framework proposed by Griesinger and Livingston in 1973.<ref name="Living73"/> In the Ring measure, subjects are asked to choose between 24 pairs of options that allocate money to the subject and the "other". The 24 pairs of outcomes correspond to equally spaced adjacent own-other-payoff allocations on an ''SVO ring'', i.e. a circle with a certain radius centered at the origin of the Cartesian plane. The vertical axis (y) measures the amount of points or money allocated to the other and the horizontal axis (x) measures the amount allocated to the self. Each pair of outcomes corresponds to two adjacent points on the circle. Adding up a subject's 24 choices yields a ''motivational vector'' with a certain length and angle. The length of the vector indicates the consistency of a subject's choice behavior, while the angle indicates that subject's SVO. Subjects are then categorized into one out of eight SVO categories according to their SVO angle, given a sufficiently consistent choice pattern. This measure allows for the detection of uncommon pathological SVOs, such as masochism, sadomasochism, or martyrdom, which would indicate that a subject attaches a negative weight (<math> a </math>) to the outcome for the self given the utility function described above.
===Triple-Dominance Measure=== The triple-dominance measure<ref>{{cite journal|last=Van Lange|first=P.A.M. |author2=Otten, W. |author3=De Bruin, E.M.N. |author4=Joireman, J.A. |title=Development of prosocial, individualistic, and competitive orientations: Theory and preliminary evidence|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|year=1997|volume=73|issue=4|pages=733–746|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.73.4.733|url=http://www.paulvanlange.com/s/VanLange1997.pdf}}</ref> is directly based on the use of ''decomposed games'' as suggested by Messick and McClintock (1968).<ref name="Messick68"/> Concretely, the triple-dominance measure consists of nine items, each of which asks a subject to choose one out of three own-other-outcome allocations. The three options do have the same characteristics in each of the items. One option maximizes the outcome for the self, a second option maximizes the sum of the outcomes for the self and the other (joint outcome), and the third option maximizes the relative gain (i.e. the difference between the outcome for the self and the outcome for the other). If a subject chooses an option indicating a particular SVO in at least six out of the nine items, the subject is categorized accordingly. That is, a subject is categorized as ''cooperative/prosocial'', ''individualistic'', or ''competitive''.
===Slider Measure=== The Slider measure<ref name=Murphy2011>{{cite journal|last=Murphy|first=R.O.|author2=Ackermann, K.A. |author3=Handgraaf, M.J.J. |title=Measuring social value orientation|journal=Journal of Judgment and Decision Making|year=2011|volume=6|issue=8|pages=771–781|url=http://www.sas.upenn.edu/~baron/journal/11/m25/m25.pdf}}</ref> assess SVO on a continuous scale, rather than categorizing subjects into [[Nominal category|nominal]] motivational groups. The instrument consists of 6 primary and 9 secondary items. In each item of the paper-based version of the Slider measure, a subject has to indicate her most preferred own-other outcome allocation out of nine options. From a subject's choices in the primary items, the ''SVO angle'' can be computed. There is also an [https://web.archive.org/web/20120208084452/http://vlab.ethz.ch/svo/SVO_Slider/SVO_Slider.html online version of the Slider measure], where subjects can ''slide'' along a continuum of own-other payoff allocations in the items, allowing for a very precise assessment of a person's SVO. The secondary items can be used for differentiating between the motivations to maximize the joint outcome and to minimize the difference in outcomes ([[inequality aversion]]) among prosocial subjects. The SVO Slider Measure has been shown to be more [[Reliability (psychometrics)|reliable]] than previously used measures, and yields SVO scores on a continuous scale.<ref name=Murphy2011/>
==Neuroscience and Social Value Orientation== Some recent papers have explored whether Social Value Orientation is somehow reflected on human brain activity. A functional magnetic resonance imaging study <ref>Christopoulos, GI & King-Casas B. (2015). With you or against you: Social orientation dependent learning signals guide actions made for others, NeuroImage, Volume 104, 1 January 2015, Pages 326-335.</ref>found that responses of Medial Prefrontal Cortex - an area that is typically associated with social cognition- mirrored preferences over competitive, individualistic and cooperative allocations. Similar findings in this or neighboring areas (ventromedial and dorsomedial prefrontal cortex) have been reported elsewhere <ref> Kuss K, Falk A, Trautner P, Montag C, Weber B, Fliessbach K. Neuronal correlates of social decision making are influenced by social value orientation—an fMRI study. Frontiers in Behavioral Neuroscience. 2015;9:40. doi:10.3389/fnbeh.2015.00040. </ref>.
==Stylized facts== SVO has been shown to be predictive of important behavioral variables, such as:
*cooperative behavior in [[social dilemma]]s <ref name=Balliet2009>{{cite journal|last=Balliet|first=D.|author2=Parks, C. |author3=Joireman, J. |title=Social value orientation and cooperation in social dilemmas: A meta-analysis|journal=Group processes & Intergroup relations|year=2009|volume=12|issue=4|pages=533–547|doi=10.1177/1368430209105040}}</ref> *[[helping behavior]] <ref>{{cite journal|last=McClintock|first=C.G.|author2=Allison, S.T. |title=Social value orientation and helping behavior|journal=Journal of Applied Social Psychology|year=1989|volume=19|issue=4|pages=353–362|doi=10.1111/j.1559-1816.1989.tb00060.x}}</ref> *[[donation|donation behavior]] <ref>{{cite journal|last=Van Lange|first=P.A.M.|author2=Bekkers, R. |author3=Schuyt, T. |author4= Van Vugt, M. |title=From games to giving: Social value orientation predicts donations to noble causes|journal=Basic and Applied Social Psychology|year=2007|volume=29|issue=4|pages=375–384|doi=10.1080/01973530701665223|url=http://www.professormarkvanvugt.com/files/FromGamestoGiving-BasicAndAppliedSocialPsychology-2007.pdf}}</ref> *[[Environmentally friendly|proenvironmental behavior]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Van Vugt|first=M. |author2=Van Lange, P.A.M. |author3=Meertens, R.M. |title=Commuting by car or public transportation? A social dilemma analysis of travel mode judgments|journal=European Journal of Social Psychology|year=1996|volume=26|issue=3 |pages=373–395|url=http://www.professormarkvanvugt.com/files/CommutingbyCarorPublicTransportation-EuropeanJournalofSocialPsychology-1996.pdf|doi=10.1002/(sici)1099-0992(199605)26:3<373::aid-ejsp760>3.3.co;2-t}}</ref> *[[negotiation|negotiation behavior]] <ref>{{cite journal|last=De Dreu|first=C.K.W. |author2=Van Lange, P.A.M. |title=The impact of social value orientations on negotiator cognition and behavior|journal=Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin|year=1995|volume=21|issue=11 |pages=1178–1188|url=http://dare.uva.nl/document/2913|doi=10.1177/01461672952111006}}</ref>
Furthermore, it has been shown that individualism is prevalent among very young children, and that the frequency of expressions of prosocial and competitive SVOs increases with age. Among adults, it has been shown repeatedly that prosocial SVOs are most frequently observed (up to 60 percent), followed by individualistic SVOs (about 30-40 percent), and competitive SVOs (about 5-10 percent). Evidence also suggests that SVO is first and foremost determined by [[socialization]], and that [[genetic predisposition]] plays a minor role in SVO development.<ref name="AuKwong2004"/>
==Broader perspectives== The SVO construct is rooted in [[Social psychology (psychology)|social psychology]], but has also been studied in other disciplines, such as [[economics]].<ref name="Offernman96">{{Cite journal| title = Value Orientations, Expectations and Voluntary Contributions in Public Goods | last = Offerman |first = T. |author2=Sonnemans J. |author3=Schram A. | year = 1996 | journal = The Economic Journal | pages = 817–845| volume = 106 | issue = 437 | doi = 10.2307/2235360 | publisher = Blackwell Publishing | jstor = 2235360}}</ref> However, the general concept underlying SVO is inherently interdisciplinary, and has been studied under different names in a variety of different scientific fields; it is the concept of distributive preferences. Originally, the SVO construct as conceptualized by the ''SVO ring framework''<ref name="Living73"/> did not include preferences such as [[inequality aversion]], which is a distributive preference heavily studied in [[experimental economics]]. This particular motivation can also not be assessed with commonly used measures of SVO, except with the ''SVO Slider Measure''.<ref name=Murphy2011/> The original SVO concept can be extended, though, by representing peoples' distributive preferences in terms of [[utility function]]s, as is standard in [[economics]]. For instance, a representation of SVO that includes the expression of a motivation to minimize differences between outcomes could be formalized as follows.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Radzicki|first=J.|title=Technique of conjoint measurement of subjective value of own and other's gains|journal=Polish Psychological Bulletin|year=1976|volume=7|issue=3|pages=179–186}}</ref>
<math> U_{(\pi_{s}, \pi_{o})} = a*\pi_{s} + b*\pi_{o} - c*|\pi_{s} - \pi_{o}| </math>.
Several utility functions as representations of peoples' concerns for the welfare of others have been devised and used (for a very prominent example, see Fehr & Schmidt, 1999<ref>{{cite journal|last=Fehr|first=E.|author2=Schmidt, K.M. |title=A theory of fairness, competition, and cooperation|journal=Quarterly Journal of Economics|year=1999|volume=114|issue=3|pages=817–868|doi=10.1162/003355399556151|url=http://qje.oxfordjournals.org/content/114/3/817.full.pdf}}</ref>) in [[economics]]. It is a challenge for future interdisciplinary research to combine the findings from different scientific disciplines and arrive at a unifying theory of SVO. Representing SVO in terms of a utility function and going beyond the construct's original conceptualization may facilitate the achievement of this ambitious goal.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==See also== * [[Social dilemma]] * [[Cooperation]] * [[Clyde Kluckhohn]] and his Social Values Orientation Theory * [[Experimental economics]] * [[Experimental psychology]] * [[Human behavior]] * [[Motivation]] * [[Rokeach Value Survey]] * [[Social preferences]] * [[Social psychology (psychology)|Social psychology]] * [[Value system]]
[[Category:Social psychology]] [[Category:Game theory]]

{{unreferenced|date=August 2011}} The '''Squeeze Box''' is an [[Magic (illusion)|illusion]] designed and originally performed by [[André Kole]].
== Effect == A person (the [[Magic (illusion)|magician]] or the [[magician's assistant|assistant]]) enters a horizontal box and extends their head out one end and their feet out of the other. A wheel is spun, squeezing both ends of the box towards the middle until the person's head is right next to their feet. The feet move throughout the effect and the person's hands can be shown out the top of the box. The box is stretched back out and the person emerges unharmed.
== Notable performances == * [[André Kole]] * [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]] * [[Siegfried and Roy]]
{{magic-stub}}
[[Category:Magic tricks]]

{{Infobox record label | name = Star Music | image_name = File:StarMusic.png | image_size = 250px | caption = The logo of Star Music (2014-present) | parent = [[Star Cinema|ABS-CBN Film Productions, Inc.]]
([[ABS-CBN|ABS-CBN Corporation]]) | founded = {{Start date and age|1995|2|df=yes}} | founder = | status = Active | distributor = Star Music Publishing (Philippines) | genre = Various | country = [[Philippines]] | location = [[ABS-CBN Broadcasting Center]], Sgt. Esguerra Avenue corner Mother Ignacia Street, Diliman, [[Quezon City]] | url = {{URL|starmusic.abs-cbn.com}} }} '''Star Music''', formerly known as '''Star Records''', is a [[record label]] in the [[Music of the Philippines|Philippines]] owned and operated by media conglomerate [[ABS-CBN]].{{cite web | url=http://ir.abs-cbn.com/Portals/_default/Skins/IR/businesses/starrecords.html?iframe=true&width=700&height=400 | title=Company Information: Star Records, Inc. | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN Corporation|ABS-CBN Investor Relations]]'' | accessdate=March 16, 2014}} It was formerly a separate company operating as a wholly owned subsidiary of ABS-CBN until 2013 when it was merged to [[Star Cinema|ABS-CBN Film Productions, Inc.]] Its publishing and distribution subsidiary in the country is Star Music Publishing (formerly Star Songs, Inc.) and has over one thousand songs in its catalog including the classic song "[[Anak (song)|Anak]]" by [[Freddie Aguilar]].{{cite web | url=http://www.starrecords.ph/starsongs/starsongs_about.asp | title=About Star Songs | publisher=''Star Records'' | accessdate=March 16, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219214221/http://www.starrecords.ph/starsongs/starsongs_about.asp | archivedate=February 19, 2012}}{{cite web | url=http://starmusic.abs-cbn.com/about-us | title=About Us | publisher=''Star Music'' | accessdate=March 16, 2014}} It is a member of the [[Philippine Association of the Record Industry]] (PARI), a non-profit and private trade organization, that represents the recording industry distributors in the Philippines.{{cite web | url=http://www.pari.com.ph/members.html | title=Corporate Members of the Philippine Association of the Record Industry | publisher=''[[Philippine Association of the Record Industry]]'' | accessdate=March 16, 2014}} ==History== Star Music was founded in February 1995 as Star Recording, Inc. with Star Records as its label. The record label was created by ABS-CBN Corporation to diversify its functions from a broadcast media to a full entertainment company. Commercial operations of the label started in September 1995, signing an exclusive distribution agreement with [[Sony Music Entertainment|Sony Music Entertainment Philippines]] (now Ivory Music and Video) in the entire country, except in Metro Manila. Due to its distribution agreement with Sony, Star Records endured problems with distributing titles in Metro Manila. In August 1996, the record label engage into licensing deals in order to strengthen its production base and gain entry into the Metro Manila market. It first signed a 3-year license agreement with JML Records, a local rock label. The deal enabled the label to gain control of its catalogue of 30 titles. Later, Star Records signed deals with foreign-independent labels such as Beaver Music of the [[Netherlands]], Music of Life of the [[United Kingdom]], and Rox of [[Belgium]].{{cite web | url=http://www.pari.com.ph/members/star.html | title=Star Records, Inc. Corporate Profile | publisher=''[[Philippine Association of the Record Industry]]'' | accessdate=March 16, 2014}} In October 1996, Star Records renewed its licensing deal with Sony which also includes 30 dealerships in Metro Manila. The deal enabled the label to get a significant presence in Metro Manila's market. By December of the same year, the label's number of signed artists increased to twenty artists. In June 1997, Star Records signed a distribution and licensing agreement with [[Taiwan]]'s [[Rock Records]], which also involved products from about forty independent European and American labels. Also under this deal, albums by named international artists helped improved Star Records' market profile. In 2007, Star Records launched Acel, the former vocalist of the rock band [[Moonstar88]], as the country's first digital artist.{{cite web | url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/music/807/songwriter-acel-to-be-launched-as-the-countrys-first-digital-artist- | title=Songwriter Acel to be launched as the country’s first digital artist | publisher=''[[Philippine Entertainment Portal]]'' | date=June 22, 2007 | accessdate=March 16, 2014}} By 2015, the record label celebrates its 20th anniversary. In 2013, Star Recording, Inc. and Star Songs, Inc. were both merged to [[Star Cinema|ABS-CBN Film Productions]]. In 2014, it changed its name to Star Music. In the same year, they launched their very own music downloading website. This is also the time where Star Music started to release their songs on iTunes, Spotify, and other music downloading and streaming websites and applications. They also revamped their YouTube channel as a response to the current trend in the consumption of music and video contents on the internet. In September 2015, Star Music acquired the copyrights to around 116 original compositions of [[Tito Sotto]], [[Vic Sotto]] and [[Joey de Leon]] which includes songs popularized by 1970s group [[VST & Co.]], [[Sharon Cuneta]], and [[Nora Aunor]], and popular songs such as "Ipagpatawad Mo", "Tayo'y Magsayawan" and "Awitin Mo, Isasayaw Ko."{{cite news|title=LOOK: Toni reunites with Tito, Vic and Joey|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/09/21/15/look-toni-reunites-tito-vic-and-joey|date=September 21, 2015|publisher=[[ABS-CBN News]]}} On January 31, 2016, after 10 years, rapper [[Gloc-9]] signed a record deal with Star Music, the record label who introduced Gloc-9 to mainstream listeners. Two of the most successful albums of Gloc-9, ''[[G9 (album)|G9]]'' and ''[[Ako Si...]]'' were released under Star Records in 2003 and 2005 respectively. These albums brought Gloc-9's biggest smash hits with songs like "Simpleng Tao" and "Hinahanap Ng Puso (feat. Hannah Romawac of Session Road)".{{cite news|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/02/01/16/gloc-9-returns-to-star-music-after-10-years|title=Gloc-9 returns to Star Music after 10 years|date=February 1, 2016|publisher=''[[ABS-CBNnews.com]]''}} ==Sub-labels== ===Active=== * Star Events - concerts and events organizer. * Star Home Video * Tarsier Records{{cite web | url=http://starcinema.abs-cbn.com/2017/8/31/news/tarsier-records-aims-to-introduce-new-wave-of-musi-29273 | title=Tarsier Records aims to introduce new wave of music to PH - and beyond | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=August 31, 2017 | accessdate=September 7, 2017}} * [[Tawag ng Tanghalan#TNT_Records|TNT Records]] - established in 2018 as the official record label of ''[[Tawag ng Tanghalan]]'' contenders, finalists, and champions. In addition, Star Music also distributes singles and albums/EPs of selected artists from OneMusicPH, a digital music website owned by [[ABS-CBN Digital Media]]. ===Defunct/Inactive=== * [[ASAP Music]] – A sub-label for the television musical variety show ''[[ASAP (variety show)|ASAP]]''. It was launched in 2006.{{cite web | url=http://asap.abs-cbn.com/page/aboutus.html | title=About Us | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | work=[[ASAP (variety show)|ASAP]] | accessdate=March 16, 2014}} * Black Bird Music – A sub-label; It is headed by [[Aiza Seguerra]], which is also the label's founder.{{cite web | url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/636283/carol-shares-piece-her-life | title=Carol shares a piece of her life | publisher=''[[The Philippine Star]]'' | date=December 6, 2010 | accessdate=March 16, 2014}} * Budget Music * Istilo Records * NuGen Records – A sub label for independent and alternative artists.{{cite web | url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/716554/star-records-signs-chiro | title=Star Records signs up Chiro | publisher=''[[The Philippine Star]]'' | date=August 15, 2011 | accessdate=March 16, 2014}} * Startraxx Records – a sub-label for film and television soundtracks. ==Notable artists== {{Hatnote|For the complete list of Star Music artists, see [[List of artists signed to Star Music]].}} {{columns-list|colwidth=20em| * [[ABS-CBN Philharmonic Orchestra]]{{cite web|url=http://starmusic.abs-cbn.com/artist|title=artist|publisher=abs-cbn.com}} (ensemble) * [[Alex Gonzaga]] * [[Angeline Quinto]] * [[Bailey May]] * [[BoybandPH]] * [[Bryan Termulo]] * [[Daniel Padilla]] * [[Daryl Ong]] * [[Donna Cruz]] * [[Ebe Dancel]] * [[Enchong Dee]] * [[Erik Santos]] * [[Gary Valenciano]] * [[Gimme 5 (group)|Gimme 5]] (pop group) * [[Harana (band)|Harana]] (pop group) * [[Jake Zyrus]] * [[Jamie Rivera]] * [[Janella Salvador]] * [[Jaya (singer)|Jaya]] * [[Jed Madela]] * [[Jericho Rosales]] * [[Jolina Magdangal]] * [[Jonalyn Viray|Jona]] * [[Jovit Baldivino]] * [[Juris Fernandez]] * [[Khalil Ramos]] * [[Kim Chiu]] * [[Kisses Delavin]] * [[Kyla]] * [[KZ Tandingan]] * [[Kathryn Bernardo]] * [[Kaye Cal]] * [[Lani Misalucha]] * [[Liezel Garcia]] * [[Marion Aunor]] * [[Maris Racal]] * [[MNL48]] (pop group) * [[Morissette Amon]] * Michael Pangilinan * [[Piolo Pascual]] * [[Reo Brothers]] (band) * [[Sam Milby]] * [[Teddy Corpuz]] * [[Toni Gonzaga]] * [[True Faith (band)|True Faith]] (band) * [[Vice Ganda]] * [[Vina Morales]] * [[Yeng Constantino]] * [[Ylona Garcia]] * [[Young JV]] }} ==Discography== {{Hatnote|For the complete Star Music discography, see [[Star Music discography]].}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://musiccatalogue.abs-cbn.com/ Star Song Music Catalogue System] {{ABS-CBN}} {{Record labels in the Philippines}} [[Category:Entertainment companies of the Philippines]] [[Category:Philippine record labels]] [[Category:Record labels established in 1995]] [[Category:Star Music| ]] [[Category:Philippine music]] [[Category:Assets owned by ABS-CBN]]

{{refimprove|date=March 2016}}
'''Stichting De Stilte''', or abbreviated '''De Stilte''', is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] dance company based in [[Breda]] focused on [[modern dance]] in combination with performing for children, but also for an adult audience.
De Stilte organizes performances as well as educational activities such as workshops, introductions and lessons. They run over 500 productions a year and is part of the basic infrastructure of the Dutch [[Ministry of Education, Culture and Science (Netherlands)|Ministry of Culture, Education and Science]] and receives a guaranteed structural funding for that.<ref>http://www.fondspodiumkunsten.nl/content/publicatie/i_026/fpkdans.pdf</ref> The organisation has two studios, one of it is a fully equipped theatre where they do public performances. Every two years the International Stiltefestival takes place in and around Breda.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.omroepbrabant.nl/?news/194704832/Dansfestival+De+Stilte+wil+steen+in+de+Bredase+vijver+gooien.aspx|title=Dansfestival De Stilte wil steen in de Bredase vijver gooien|work=Omroep Brabant}}</ref> The organisation tours regularly worldwide, besides their activities in the Netherlands. In 2015 De Stilte was no.82 in the Dutch Cultuur Top 100 of [[NRC Handelsblad]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dansmagazine.nl/nieuws/danswereld-goed-vertegenwoordigd-nrc-cultuur-top-100|title=Danswereld goed vertegenwoordigd in NRC Cultuur Top 100|work=Dans Magazine}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} [http://www.nrc.nl/handelsblad/2015/11/26/voorstellingen-de-stilte-in-parijs-afgelast-1564258 De Stilte] in [[NRC Handelsblad]]
==External links== * [http://www.destilte.nl/en/ Official website of De Stilte]

{{Infobox Podcast |title = ''Straight Talk with Ross Mathews |image = |caption = |hosting = [[Ross Mathews]], CJay (Chris Jordan), Fagsy Malone, & Nikki B., and Mark. |language = English |rss = |atom = |updates = |length = |camera = |direction = |production = Joshua Rodriguez (previously: Will Sterling and Rich Boerner) |picture format = |video format = |audio format = |began = November 06, 2014 |ended = |genre = Comedy, Entertainment, Advice, Talk |ratings = |cited_for = |cited_as = |provider = [[Wondery]] |license = |url = [http://www.straighttalkwithross.com/ ''Straight Talk with Ross''] |opentheme = "Straight Talk" by [[Dolly Parton]] |Misc = |Audio caption = |picture =}} '''''Straight Talk with Ross Mathews''''' ('''''STWR''''') is a weekly [[podcast]] described as "Advice & LOLs from the Gay Best Friend You Wish You Had and Know You Need," hosted by [[Ross Mathews]].{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/more/news/ross-mathews-sirius-xm-show-1201612521/|title=Ross Mathews to Host SiriusXM Show ‘Straight Talk with Ross Mathews’ - Variety|author=Elizabeth Wagmeister|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=16 January 2016}}{{Cite web|title = Straight Talk with Ross Mathews|url = http://podcastone.com/Straight-Talk-with-Ross-Mathews|website = podcastone.com|access-date = 2016-01-16}}{{Citation|title = Ross Mathews Talks "Straight Talk With Ross" & His First Experience With A Woman|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g77AfId28h4|date = 2015-05-12|accessdate = 2016-01-16}}{{Cite web|title = Ross Mathews Gets His Own Podcast! Get the Scoop|url = http://www.eonline.com/news/594402/ross-mathews-to-host-his-own-podcast-called-straight-talk-with-ross-mathews|website = E! Online|access-date = 2016-01-16|language = en-US}} The audio podcasts are typically between an hour to an hour and a half in length and feature celebrity interviews and discussion on pop-culture and current events. The show was first released on November 11, 2014. The show's theme song is "[[Straight Talk]]" by [[Dolly Parton]]. The program features segments including Pre-Podcast Prayer Circle, Press-Conference, Snack Attack!, Weight-Update, Are You Smarter Than Mark, Trending with Daria, Nikki B. Trending, Minute Mark, United Straights of America, Teen Talk with Jordan, Balls Deep with Fagsy, Movie Critic Bill's Movie Reviews, BrendaGnocchi! (Brandon Karaoke), Ross Report, Brenda's 3 Questions, Simply The Best (STB), The Blackness, Kiss Kiss and Tell, Pick Ross' Brain, Dr. Top/Bottom, Latina Turner, and Shart Tank. The show features regulars, co-hosts, and celebrity guests.{{Cite web|title = straighttalkwithross.com|url = http://straighttalkwithross.com|website = straighttalkwithross.com|access-date = 2016-01-16}}
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/straight-talk-ross-mathews/id935740416?mt=2 Straight Talk with Ross Mathews on iTunes] [[Category:English-language podcasts]] [[Category:Comedy and humor podcasts]] [[Category:American talk radio programs]] [[Category:Sirius XM Radio]] [[Category:LGBT-related podcasts]] [[Category:LGBT-related radio programs]] [[Category:2010s LGBT-related media]]

{{Infobox video game |title = Suikoden Tactics |image = Box-lt.jpg |image_size = 256px |developer = [[Konami]] |publisher = Konami |artist = [[Junko Kawano]] |writer = Junko Kawano |composer = Norikazu Miura |series = ''[[Suikoden]]'' |released = {{vgrelease|JP|September 22, 2005|NA|November 8, 2005|EU|February 24, 2006}} |genre = [[Tactical role-playing game]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[PlayStation 2]] }}
'''''Suikoden Tactics''''', originally released in [[Japan]] as {{nihongo|'''''Rhapsodia'''''|ラプソディア|Rapusodia}}, is a [[tactical role-playing game|tactical role-playing video game]] developed and published by [[Konami]] for the [[PlayStation 2]] console as part of their ''[[Suikoden]]'' series. Initially released in Japan and North America in late 2005, the game was later made available in Europe and the PAL region in early 2006. It is the first strategy-based installment of the series, using tactical, grid-based combat instead of the [[turn-based strategy|turn-based]] battles employed by previous games in the series. The game's music was composed by series veteran Norikazu Miura and features the opening theme "Another World" performed by Japanese vocalist yoshiko.
The game's [[fantasy]] story is told in two parts, taking place both before and after the events of ''[[Suikoden IV]]'' released one year earlier, and features appearances by characters from the title. Players assume the role of Kyril, a young man investigating the power of mysterious weapons called "Rune Cannons," which hold strange powers of transformation.
==Gameplay== [[Image:Suikodentactics.jpg|thumb|left|200px|A battle sequence]] ''Suikoden Tactics'' is a [[tactical role-playing game]] and thus shares many traits with the [[genre]]. The player controls a young man named Kyril, and advances the plot by completing tactical battles and talking with other characters. The player can also recruit new characters to his cause, which often involves a short [[sidequest]]. In towns, the player can gather information, sharpen character's weaponry, learn new skills, and buy equipment. Each character may use special "Runes" or items to imbue terrain squares with various elements. Characters each have a particular element on which their attack and defence is boosted by a significant amount when they occupy a space with the corresponding element, and the reverse is true if the character occupies a space with an element the character is weak to.
Another feature of the battle system in Suikoden Tactics is its use of supporting characters. Such characters have no offensive value, as they can not attack, but impart various effects on the playing field such as healing, stealing, digging, and stat buffing.
Aside from that, the elemental runes and weapon runes from previous games return. Elemental Runes all have as their level 1 spell, a magic that turns an area of the playing field of a certain element. Weapon runes in Suikoden Tactics operate differently from previous Suikoden games. Instead of a single attack with infinite uses, weapon runes impart three different attacks that operate similarly to spell runes, as each attack is defined by a certain number of charges before it can no longer be used, although all MP would be recharged upon a level-up.
==Story==
The story of ''Suikoden Tactics'' begins about seven years before the events of ''[[Suikoden IV]]'', and establishes the reason why Kyril is determined to search out and destroy the Rune Cannons. The prequel part of Suikoden Tactics ends with a traumatic event for Kyril, and how Brandeau gains the possession of the Rune of Punishment.
The game leaps forward about three years after the events of ''Suikoden IV'' takes place. From here on, Kyril begins his investigation on Rune Cannons and eventually leads him north into the Kooluk Empire. Kyril meets a mysterious man, Iskas, who hints at a connection between Rune Cannons and Kooluk. From there, Kyril investigates further about connections between Kooluk and Rune Cannons, and soon leads Kyril to Kika and her pirate crew. Clues turn Kyril's journey north, first to the fortress of El Eal, then finally into the Kooluk Empire itself.
During his investigation in the Kooluk Empire, Kyril and his company meets up with a young aristocrat girl named Corselia, who is later revealed as the granddaughter of the Emperor of the Kooluk Empire. It is also here that Iskas finally reveals his real intentions and begins a plot to antagonize Kyril.
==Soundtrack== The music for ''Suikoden Tactics'' was composed and arranged by [[Norikazu Miura]], who would go on to also compose the soundtrack of ''[[Suikoden V]]''. The opening theme "Another World" was performed by [[yoshiko]].<!-- Lowercase intentional.--> The music was released first as the ''Rhapsodia Privilege Collection'' was released on September 22, 2005. It is a single CD containing selected tracks from the game as well as remixes from other ''Suikoden'' soundtracks. It also features a preview of "Castle of Dawn," the music for the Ceras Lake castle in ''[[Suikoden V]]'', which was at the time unpublished. A week later on September 28, the ''Rhapsodia Original Soundtrack'' was released as a full compilation of the music in the game over 2 CDs.
{{clear}}
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = 68 / 100<ref name="MC">{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-2/suikoden-tactics |title=Suikoden Tactics for PlayStation 2 Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref> | EGM = 7.33 / 10<ref>{{cite journal |title=Suikoden Tactics |author=EGM staff |magazine=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]] |issue=198 |date=December 2005}}</ref> | EuroG = 5 / 10<ref name="Euro">{{cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/r_suikodentactics_ps2 |title=Suikoden Tactics |last=Parkin |first=Simon |date=March 28, 2006 |publisher=[[Eurogamer]] |accessdate=March 22, 2009}}</ref> | Fam = 31 / 40<ref name="Fami">{{cite web |url=http://www.neogaf.com/forum/showthread.php?t=63016&page=1 |title=Famitsu scores |publisher=[[NeoGAF]] |date=September 14, 2005 |accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref> | GI = 6.75 / 10<ref name="GI">{{cite journal |title=Suikoden Tactics |last=Juba |first=Joe |magazine=[[Game Informer]] |issue=152 |date=December 2005 |page=174}}</ref> | GSpot = 7.6 / 10<ref name="GSpot">{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/suikoden-tactics-review/1900-6139766/ |title=Suikoden Tactics Review |last=Mueller |first=Greg |date=November 14, 2005 |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref> | GSpy = {{Rating|3|5}}<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ps2.gamespy.com/playstation-2/genso-suikoden-tactics/670495p1.html |title=GameSpy: Suikoden Tactics |last=Fischer |first=Russ |date=November 23, 2005 |publisher=[[GameSpy]] |accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref> | GameZone = 6.6 / 10<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamezone.com/reviews/suikoden_tactics_ps2_review |title=Suikoden Tactics - PS2 - Review |last=Grabowski |first=Dakota |date=November 30, 2005 |publisher=GameZone |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006081219/http://ps2.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r27145.htm |archivedate=October 6, 2008 |deadurl=no |accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref> | IGN = 7.3 / 10<ref name="IGN">{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2005/11/08/suikoden-tactics |title=Suikoden Tactics |last=Dunham |first=Jeremy |date=November 7, 2005 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref> | OPM = {{Rating|3|5}}<ref name="OPM">{{cite journal |title=Suikoden Tactics |magazine=[[Official U.S. PlayStation Magazine]] |issue=96 |date=December 2005 |page=118}}</ref> | XPlay = {{Rating|3|5}}<ref name="XPlay">{{cite web |url=http://www.g4tv.com/xplay/features/53335/Suikoden_Tactics_Review.html |title=Suikoden Tactics Review |last=Sewart |first=Greg |date=January 31, 2006 |publisher=''[[X-Play]]'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060907092425/http://www.g4tv.com/xplay/features/53335/Suikoden_Tactics_Review.html |archivedate=September 7, 2006 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref> }}
''Suikoden Tactics'' was met with a fairly positive response in Japan, selling approximately 64,472 within its first year, enough to qualify it for a re-release under [[Sony]]'s "PlayStation the Best" distinction in November 2006 at a budget price.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gensopedia.duefiumi.com/index.php?title=Suikoden_sales_figures |title=Suikoden sales figures |publisher=Gensopedia |date=July 3, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002150432/http://gensopedia.duefiumi.com/index.php?title=Suikoden_sales_figures |archivedate=October 2, 2008 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref> ''[[Famitsu]]'' gave it a score of two eights, one seven, and one eight for a total of 31 out of 40.<ref name="Fami" />
The game received "average" reviews according to the [[Review aggregator|review aggregation]] website [[Metacritic]].<ref name="MC" /> [[GameSpot]] praised the game's user-friendliness and battle design, stating that the game was "fun for veterans and newcomers alike", yet found the game's "weak story and characters" and "spotty voice acting" to be its low points.<ref name="GSpot" /> [[IGN]] also found the game's battle system to be engaging, but ultimately declared the game's plot to be "paltry", urging the player to "[e]xpect more from battles rather than plotlines."<ref name="IGN" /> Conversely, ''[[Game Informer]]'' found the game too confusing with haphazard battle scenes, stating, "I'd rather have a simple and well-balanced game than a complicated and lopsided one, and ''Suikoden Tactics'' definitely has too many short legs."<ref name="GI" /> ''[[Official U.S. PlayStation Magazine]]'' stated that the gameplay "works when it's not broken", but was hindered by "boring" story sequences and "awful" graphics.<ref name="OPM" />
[[Eurogamer]] found the game to be lackluster when compared to other tactical-based role-playing games, particularly those developed by [[Nippon Ichi Software]], declaring that ''Suikoden Tactics''{{'}}s "[b]attles are fun and fairly compulsive but this is a game we've played many times over, usually presented better, executed more beautifully and intertwined with a far superior story."<ref name="Euro" /> [[G4 (U.S. TV channel)|G4]]'s ''[[X-Play]]'' echoed their sentiment, stating that "despite some interesting play mechanics, it's not nearly as deep as some of the other games on the market right now."<ref name="XPlay" />
{{clear}}

'''''TV Times''''' was an Australian [[magazine]], issued weekly, first published as a [[Sydney, Australia|Sydney]]-only publication in June 1958. The publication previewed upcoming storylines for popular television programs airing in Australia, featured interviews and a full weekly program guide. It was a long time rival to ''[[TV Week]]'' magazine until it was incorporated into that magazine in 1980.
== History == "TV Times" evolved out of a magazine titled ''TV News'', launched by the [[ABC Television|ABC]] in June 1958. It joined rival publications ''Television Preview'', produced by the Television Owners Club of Australia and launched in 1957, and an Australian Consolidated Press magazine titled "TV Times". They were joined in July 1958 by a Sydney edition of ''TV Week'', which had been publishing in Melbourne since December 1957 as ''TV-Radio Week''.
It was thought that four television titles in the market was unsustainable so ACP entered into a co-publishing deal with the ABC, which saw their respective magazines merged to become ''TV News-Times'' (soon simplified to ''TV Times''). By the end of the year, ''Television Preview'' was incorporated into ''TV Week'', leaving two rival publications in the market for the next two decades. ''TV Times'' notably gave far more space and cover stories to ABC programs than its rival.
''TV Times'' began a Melbourne edition in August 1959. Both ''TV Times'' and ''TV Week'' continued to expand publication as television launched in other capital cities and regional areas across Australia. By 1961, there were editions covering every capital city except Hobart, which received Melbourne editions plus a local supplement.<ref>{{cite web|author=Chris Keating|url=http://www.austlit.edu.au/austlit/page/9548170|title=Television Magazines|work=Austlit|date=18 November 2016|accessdate=1 February 2017}}</ref>
''TV Week'' introduced a viewer-voted awards from 1958 called the "Logie Awards" (after John Logie Baird), so TV Times created the rival Australian Film and Television Awards called the "Sammy Awards" from 1976.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://televisionau.com/2009/10/1979-october-13-19.html|title=1979: October 13-19|work=Television.AU|date=2009|accessdate=1 February 2017}}</ref>
While ''TV Times'' was arguably regarded as more informative, ''TV Week'' began to lead by adding matte colour internal pages in 1962, while ''TV Times'' did little to stay ahead. In July 1968, when ''TV Week'' moved to a larger format, to match that of ''TV Times'', it immediately looked superior to its rival with glossy colour pages and a cleaner layout. Even when ''TV Times'' became a full-colour publication, the quality was considered inferior to that of ''TV Week''.
In 1979, Southdown Press introduced a local version of the American ''"[[TV Guide]]"''. In 1980, the ABC elected to end its agreement with ACP, which purchased the ABC's interest in ''TV Times''. ACP entered into a partnership with News Limited, with ''TV Times'' immediately being incorporated into ''TV Week'' and the Australian version of ''TV Guide'' also incorporated that year. The revamped publication continued to be known as ''TV Week'' but was now a joint venture between [[Australian Consolidated Press]] and Southdown Press (later [[Pacific Publications]]).
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
'''[[Netflix]]''' is an American-based company that offers a service for streaming movies and TV series over the [[Internet]]. Several technical development efforts were required to provide this service.
== Streaming == Initial [[DVD]] discs sent to customers via US mail often received criticisms of being scratched and unable to fully play the rented movie. The popularity of Netflix dramatically increased with the addition of streaming through an online queue. This led to the majority of Netflix users reliably streaming movies and television shows rather than receiving physical DVD discs by mail.
Initially streaming starting in 2007 solely using [[Microsoft]] technologies and codecs such as [[VC-1]] for video and [[Windows Media Audio]] (WMA) for audio, the rapid expansion and diversity of Netflix-capable devices have necessitated encoding into many different formats – including [[H.264]] (AVC), VC-1, [[H.263]] and [[High Efficiency Video Coding|H.265 (HEVC)]] for video, and [[Dolby Digital]], [[Dolby Digital Plus]], [[Advanced Audio Coding]] (AAC) and [[Ogg Vorbis]] for audio.<ref name="history">{{cite web |url= http://blog.streamingmedia.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/2013SMEast-C101.pdf|title= A Brief History of Netflix Streaming |author= David Ronca |date= May 31, 2013 |accessdate= September 12, 2016 }}</ref> According to Netflix, the vast number of codec and bitrate combinations can mean having to encode the same title 120 different times before it can be delivered to all streaming platforms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://techblog.netflix.com/2012/12/complexity-in-digital-supply-chain.html|title=Complexity In The Digital Supply Chain|author=McEntee, Kevin|date=December 17, 2012}}</ref>
Netflix uses [[adaptive bitrate streaming]] technology to adjust the video and audio quality to match a customer's broadband connection speed and realtime network conditions.
In 2015, [[BT Group|BT]]'s [[YouView]] launched [[Ultra-high-definition television|Ultra HD]] channels and a 4K box to watch it on in the UK.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 4K Netflix comes to YouView thanks to BT: Watch Ultra HD shows and films on your box – Pocket-lint|url = http://www.pocket-lint.com/news/136230-4k-netflix-comes-to-youview-thanks-to-bt-watch-ultra-hd-shows-and-films-on-your-box|website = www.pocket-lint.com|accessdate = 2015-12-21}}</ref> As of December 2015, Netflix's 4K catalogue can be watched on BT's Ultra HD box. In order to stream the Ultra HD content, users need the top-tier subscription option.<ref>{{Cite web|title = BT's Ultra HD box can now stream Netflix in 4K|url = https://www.engadget.com/2015/12/21/bt-box-netflix-4k/|website = Engadget|accessdate = 2015-12-21}}</ref>
Netflix provides users the ability to choose their download rates quality of video on its website.
== Netflix API == On October 1, 2008, Netflix offered access to its service via a public [[application programming interface]] (API).<ref>{{cite web |title=Netflix API Launches Tomorrow |url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/netflix_api_launches_tomorrow.php |publisher=ReadWriteWeb |accessdate=September 30, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002035838/http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/netflix_api_launches_tomorrow.php |archivedate=October 2, 2008 |df= }}</ref> The Netflix API allows access to data for all Netflix titles as well as access on a user's behalf to manage his or her movie queue. The API was free and allowed commercial use.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mashery.com/customers/netflix |title=Netflix API Management Solution |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130216123114/http://www.mashery.com/customers/netflix |archivedate=2013-02-16 |df= }}</ref> A developer network included a forum for asking and answering questions.<ref name="HackingNetflix">{{cite web| title=New York Times & Rotten Tomatoes Add Netflix "Add" & "Watch" Links |url=http://www.hackingnetflix.com/2009/02/ny-times-rotten-tomatoes-add-netflix-add-play-links.html |publisher=HackingNetflix |accessdate=February 20, 2009 }}</ref>
Examples of using the service included [[Rotten Tomatoes]] and ''[[The New York Times]]'', which allow users to click to add titles to their Netflix queue or begin watching on "Watch Instantly" from their pages,<ref name="HackingNetflix" /> and [[Jinni (search engine)|Jinni]], which enabled one to search within Watch Instantly and imported some user information such as reviews.<ref>{{cite web| title=Jinni Searches Netflix better than Netflix |url= http://news.cnet.com/8301-17939_109-10199106-2.html |publisher=CNET |accessdate=March 18, 2009 }}</ref>
The API allowed developers to release Netflix applications for mobile devices. For example, on November 16, 2009, Netflix released an official [[Nokia phone|Nokia]] app that allowed some trailer streaming,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://blog.netflix.com/2009/11/netflix-for-nokia-phones.html |title= Netflix for Nokia Phones |accessdate =April 2, 2011 |last= Hart |first= Michael |date= November 16, 2009 |publisher=Netflix}}</ref> and on August 26, 2010, Netflix released an official iPhone app.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.netflix.com/2010/04/netflix-on-iphone.html |title=Netflix on iPhone? |date=April 2, 2010 |publisher=Netflix |accessdate=July 19, 2010}}</ref> However, in June 2012, Netflix began to cut back the availability of its public API.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://developer.netflix.com/blog/read/Upcoming_Changes_to_the_Netflix_API_Program |title= Upcoming Changes to the Netflix API Program |accessdate= June 21, 2012 |date= June 15, 2012 |publisher= Netflix |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120618004836/http://developer.netflix.com/blog/read/Upcoming_Changes_to_the_Netflix_API_Program |archivedate= June 18, 2012 |df= }}</ref> The company instead focused on a small number of known partners using private interfaces, since most of the traffic came from those private interfaces.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Netflix API: Top 10 Lessons Learned (so far) |author= Daniel Jacobson and Sangeeta Narayanan |date= July 24, 2014 |url= http://www.slideshare.net/danieljacobson/top-10-lessons-learned-from-the-netflix-api-oscon-2014 |accessdate= September 12, 2016 }}</ref> In June 2014, Netflix announced that they would be retiring the public API. This became effective November 14, 2014.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Netflix is shutting down its public API today |date= November 14, 2014 |author= Janko Roettgers |work= GigaOm |url= https://gigaom.com/2014/11/14/netflix-is-shutting-down-its-public-api-today/ |accessdate= September 12, 2016 }}</ref> Netflix then partnered with the developers of eight services deemed to have been the most valuable, including Instant Watcher, Fanhattan, Yidio, and Nextguide.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://developer.netflix.com/blog/read/Retiring_the_Netflix_Public_API |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20140614024656/http://developer.netflix.com/blog/read/Retiring_the_Netflix_Public_API |dead-url= yes |archive-date= June 14, 2014 |title= Retiring the Netflix Public API |accessdate= August 11, 2014 |last= Jacobson |first= Daniel |date= June 13, 2014 |publisher= Netflix }}</ref>
== Information technology == In 2010, Netflix moved to using [[Amazon EC2]] for its [[information technology]] (IT) resources. Master copies of digital films from [[movie studio]]s are stored on [[Amazon S3]], and each film is encoded into over 50 different versions based on video resolution and audio quality using machines on the [[cloud computing|cloud]]. In total, Netflix has over 1 [[petabyte]] of data stored on Amazon,{{When|date=September 2016}} and the data is sent to [[content delivery network]]s (including [[Akamai Technologies]], [[Limelight Networks]] and [[Level 3 Communications]]) that feed the content to local [[Internet service provider|ISPs]]. Netflix uses a number of pieces of [[open-source software]] in its [[Backend as a service|backend]], including [[Java (software platform)|Java]], [[MySQL]], [[Gluster]], [[Apache Tomcat]], [[Apache Hive|Hive]], Chukwa, [[Apache Cassandra|Cassandra]] and [[Apache Hadoop|Hadoop]].<ref>{{YouTube|id=Idu9OKnAOis|title=OSCON Data 2011, Adrian Cockcroft, "Data Flow at Netflix"}}</ref>
In June, 2012, a storm in the Eastern US caused power outages in a major Amazon data center. This caused a three-hour downtime in Netflix services, and resulted in some improvements to the Netflix recovery software.<ref>{{Cite news |title= Netflix uncovers its own system faults following Amazon cloud outage |author= Yevgeniy Sverdlik |date= July 6, 2012 |work= Data Center Dynamics |url= http://www.datacenterdynamics.com/content-tracks/colo-cloud/netflix-uncovers-its-own-system-faults-following-amazon-cloud-outage/66596.article |accessdate= September 15, 2016 }}</ref> Another outage was experienced on December 24, 2012.<ref>{{Cite news |title= Netflix streaming down on some devices due to Amazon issues |work= The Verge |author= Bryan Bishop |date= December 24, 2012 |url= https://www.theverge.com/2012/12/24/3801978/netflix-streaming-down-on-some-devices-thanks-to-amazon-issues |accessdate= September 15, 2016 }}</ref>
Netflix developed several technologies to help manage its IT systems, an area known as [[DevOps]]. One tool is called the "simian army", which includes the "[[Chaos Monkey]]".<ref>{{Cite web |title= What is Simian Army? |work= Git Hub |url= https://github.com/Netflix/SimianArmy/wiki |accessdate= September 12, 2016 }}</ref> By intentionally creating different failures, the ability to survive them can be tested under controlled conditions before they affect customers. The technology is claimed under at least one patent, filed in 2010 with inventors Gregory S. Orzell and Yury Izrailevsky.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Validating the resiliency of networked applications |work= US Patent US20120072571 A1 |date= September 20, 2010 |author= Gregory S. Orzell and Yury Izrailevsky |url= https://www.google.com/patents/US20120072571 |accessdate= September 12, 2016 }} Published March 22, 2012</ref> Similar approaches were taken in the GameDay software by [[Jesse Robbins]] at [[Amazon.com]], "DIRT" created by at [[Google]], and others.<ref>{{cite journal|author2=Jesse Robbins|author2link=Jesse Robbins|author3=Kripa Krishnan|author4=John Allspaw|author=Tom Limoncelli|authorlink=Tom Limoncelli|title=Resilience Engineering: Learning to Embrace Failure |url= http://queue.acm.org/detail.cfm?id=2371297 |journal=ACM Queue |date= September 12, 2012 |accessdate= September 12, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title= Chaos Lemur: Testing High Availability on Pivotal Cloud Foundry |author= Paul Harris |date= May 1, 2015 |url= https://blog.pivotal.io/pivotal-cloud-foundry/products/chaos-lemur-testing-high-availability-on-pivotal-cloud-foundry |accessdate= September 12, 2016 }}</ref> The related software was made available on [[GitHub]] in 2012.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Chaos Monkey Released Into The Wild |author= Cory Bennett and Ariel Tseitlin |work= The Nteflix Tech Blog |date= July 30, 2012 |url= http://techblog.netflix.com/2012/07/chaos-monkey-released-into-wild.html |accessdate= September 12, 2016 }}</ref> This approach has been used for case studies,<ref>{{Cite web |title= DevOps Case Study: Netflix and the Chaos Monkey |date= April 30, 2015 |author= C. Arron Cois |publisher= Software Engineering Institute |url= https://insights.sei.cmu.edu/devops/2015/04/devops-case-study-netflix-and-the-chaos-monkey.html |accessdate= September 12, 2016 }}</ref> and as the title of a 2016 memoir on a life in [[Silicon Valley]], ''[[Chaos Monkeys]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Chaos Monkeys |work= Blog |author= García Martínez |url= http://www.antoniogarciamartinez.com/chaos-monkeys/ |accessdate= September 12, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title= Chaos Monkey and Neutron |date= January 29, 2015 |url= http://go.bigswitch.com/rs/974-WXR-561/images/Chaos%20Monkey%20-%20OpenStack%20-%20Big%20Cloud%20Fabric.pdf |accessdate= September 12, 2016 }}</ref>
== Open Connect == Netflix settlement freely [[peering|peers]] with [[Internet service provider]]s (ISPs) directly and at common [[Internet exchange point]]s. In June 2012, a custom [[content delivery network]] called Open Connect was announced.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Netflix Rolls Out Its Own CDN: Open Connect |date= June 4, 2016 |author= Ryan Lawler |work= Tech Crunch |url= https://techcrunch.com/2012/06/04/netflix-open-connect/ |accessdate= September 12, 2016 }}</ref> For larger ISPs that have over 100,000 subscribers Netflix offers free ''Netflix Open Connect'' [[server appliance]]s that cache Netflix content within the ISPs' [[data center]]s or networks to further reduce [[Internet transit]] costs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.netflix.com/openconnect|title=Netflix Open Connect Content Delivery Network|work=netflix.com|accessdate=October 25, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ericsavitz/2012/06/05/netflix-shifts-traffic-to-its-own-cdn-akamai-limelight-shrs-hit/|title=Netflix Shifts Traffic To Its Own CDN; Akamai, Limelight Shrs Hit|author=Eric Savitz|date=June 5, 2012|work=Forbes|accessdate=October 25, 2014}}</ref> The Open Connect appliances are purpose-built servers that focus on low power and high storage density, and run the [[FreeBSD]] operating system, [[nginx]] and the [[Bird Internet routing daemon]].<ref name="cdn2013">{{Cite web |title= Netflix Content Delivery |work= Content Delivery Summit |date= May 22, 2013 |url= http://blog.streamingmedia.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/2013CDNSummit-Keynote-Netflix.pdf |accessdate= September 12, 2016 }}</ref> By August 2016, Netflix closed its last physical data center, but continued to develop its Open Connect technology.<ref>{{Cite news |title= Netflix's data centers are dead, long live the CDN! |author= Peter Judge |date= August 20, 2015 |work= Data Center Dynamics |url= http://www.datacenterdynamics.com/content-tracks/colo-cloud/netflixs-data-centers-are-dead-long-live-the-cdn/94661.fullarticle |accessdate= September 15, 2016 }}</ref>
A 2016 study at the [[University of London]] detected 233 individual locations over six continents, with the largest amount of traffic in the USA, followed by Mexico.<ref>{{Cite news |title= Boffins map Netflix's Open Connect CDN: Six continents, 233 locations, thousands of servers |author= Richard Chirgwin |date= June 22, 2016 |work= The Register |url= https://www.theregister.co.uk/2016/06/22/boffins_map_netflixs_open_connect_cdn/ |accessdate= September 15, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title= Open Connect Everywhere: A Glimpse at the Internet Ecosystem through the Lens of the Netflix CDN |journal=ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communications Review |volume= 48 |issue= 1 |orig-year=Submitted June 17, 2017 |date=January 2018 |first1=Timm |last1=Böttger |first2=Felix |last2=Cuadrado |first3=Gareth |last3=Tyson |first4=Ignacio |last4=Castro |first5=Steve |last5=Uhlig |arxiv= 1606.05519 |bibcode=2016arXiv160605519B }}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
{{Netflix}}
[[Category:Netflix]] [[Category:Streaming]] [[Category:Video rental services]]

'''Teknofest Istanbul''', short for '''Teknofest Istanbul Aerospace and Technology Festival''', is a festival of aviation, aerospace and technology to be held at [[Istanbul New Airport]] of [[Turkey]] between 20–23 September 2018. Organized by the Turkish Technology Team Foundation (T3), it aims to help develop public awareness for technology especially for the national production.<ref name="ti"/><ref name="hdn1"/> The event is sponsored by government government bodies, private companies and academic institutions.<ref name="ds1"/>
Activities, which will take place during the festival, are seminars, award-winning technology competitions, exhibitions of domestic technology enterprises, a summit of international venture and aviation demonstrations, including parachuting, air shows of "Solo Turk", "[[Turkish Stars]]" and international professional aviation teams.<ref name="ds1"/><ref name="hdn1"/>
Technology competitions are organized in 12 different categories. A wide range of age groups, from secondary school students to oniversity graduates, are allowed to develop their projects with the help of technical equipment.<ref name="ds1"/>
For the contest "The HackIstanbul 2018 Capture the Flag", organized in cooperation with the [[European Cyber Security Organization]] (ECSO) and Romanian Government, computer [[hacker]]s from all over the world are expected to compete. For the winners in the first three places, money awards are provided.<ref name="ds1"/>
Another award-winning competition is the "World Drone Cup" race.<ref name="wdc"/>
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name="ti">{{cite web |url=https://www.teknofestistanbul.org/en |publisher=Teknofest Istanbul |title=About |accessdate=12 September 2018 }}</ref> <ref name="ds1">{{cite news |url=https://www.dailysabah.com/technology/2018/09/09/hackers-from-over-130-countries-to-compete-in-teknofest-istanbul-hackathon |newspaper=[[Daily Sabah]] |title=Hackers from over 130 countries to compete in Teknofest Istanbul hackathon |date=9 September 2018 |accessdate=12 September 2018 }}</ref> <ref name="wdc">{{cite web |url=https://worlddronecup.com/about/ |publisher=World Drone Cup |title=About |accessdate=12 September 2018 }}</ref> <ref name="hdn1">{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkeys-largest-tech-fest-to-be-held-in-istanbul-this-month-136459 |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |title=Turkey’s largest tech fest to be held in Istanbul this month |date=4 September 2018 |accessdate=12 September 2018 }}</ref> }}

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=December 2007}} {{Infobox television |show_name = The NBC Monday Movie |image = |caption = |show_name_2 = '''NBC Monday Night at the Movies'''''
'''''NBC Wednesday Night at the Movies'''''
'''''The NBC Tuesday Night Movie''' |genre = |country = United States |language = [[English language|English]] |num_seasons = |num_episodes = |list_episodes = |runtime = 120 mins. (approx) |channel = [[NBC]] |first_aired = February 4, 1963 - 2003 |last_aired = }} '''''The NBC Monday Movie''''' was a television [[anthology series]] of films that debuted on February 4, 1963 (in the middle of the [[1962–63 United States network television schedule|1962-63 season)]], and ran off on [[NBC]]. It was referred to as '''''NBC Monday Night at the Movies''''' prior to the mid-1980s. The show moved to Wednesday nights in 1964 as '''''NBC Wednesday Night at the Movies''''', and in 1965, the program moved to Tuesdays, under the title '''''The NBC Tuesday Night Movie'''''. The name would henceforth change depending on what night of the week the program was telecast. By 1968, there was once again a weekly '''''NBC Monday Night Movie''''' on the air.[https://web.archive.org/web/20080314052510/http://www.getty.net/texts/tv-67-83.txt http://www.getty.net/texts/tv-67-83.txt] (Cached by [[Internet Archive]]) ==Background== The idea for the show came about when advertisers opted out of two hour-long shows the network ran on Monday nights for the 1962-1963 season, ''[[It's a Man's World (TV series)|It's A Man's World]]'' and ''[[Saints and Sinners (1962 TV series)|Saints and Sinners]]''. Presumably, both shows were cancelled due to low audience numbers. Having experienced some success with [[NBC Saturday Night at the Movies]], the network decided to acquire more [[feature film]]s as a stop-gap measure. A package of 42 movies from [[20th Century Fox]] and 35 titles from [[MGM]] were purchased by the network for both its Monday and Saturday night movie series at a cost of $14 million.UPI Interview with Don Bays, in charge of movies at NBC. Western Kansas Press, Great Bend, April 27, 1963 With a 7:30 pm (EST) start time, the movies of the show's first season were made up of mostly light comedies, an occasional swashbuckler such as ''[[Prince Valiant (1954 film)|Prince Valiant]]'', and musicals. These types of films were also chosen because they typically ran under 100 minutes, the normal running-time for a two-hour movie slot in 1963. In the latter years of ''Monday Night Movie's'' run, mostly [[Television movie|made-for-TV movie]]s were showcased. The theatrical films were [[Editing|edited]] for content, to remove objectionable material, and occasionally, but not always, to reduce the film's running time to fit into the two-hour time slot. As all widescreen films were then, they were [[pan-and-scan]]ned so the image would fit the standard 4:3 television screen (as opposed to [[letterbox]] format). An exception was [[Show Boat (1951 film)|the 1951 film version of "Show Boat"]], which made its television debut on ''NBC Monday Night at the Movies'' in 1972 and had not been filmed in widescreen. The choice of ''Show Boat'' as a movie offering on the program was rather unusual, given the fact that it was, at the time, a twenty-one-year-old film, rather than a recent one. ==The first two series of films (February 1963-April 1964)== The first incarnation of ''NBC Monday Night at the Movies'' lasted from February 1963 until early September 1964. Despite the promise of big name stars each week, the series was no match for the [[CBS]] lineup of game shows and sitcoms such as ''[[The Lucy Show]]'' and ''[[The Danny Thomas Show]]''. In hopes of better ratings and to re-coup some of their investment, the films in the second list below would be re-broadcast on ''[[NBC Saturday Night at the Movies]]'' in the late spring and summer of 1964.TV Listings Pages;San Antonio Light Newspaper; San Antonio, TX; September 1963-April 1964 Unless otherwise indicated, all films aired from 7:30pm–9:30pm Eastern Time on Monday Nights. The last number in the second list below notes the Nielsen rating the movie received:http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-BC/BC-1969/1969-11-03-BC.pdf These first sixteen titles (all produced by 20th Century Fox studios) were aired on the following dates:February–May 1963 TV listings of ''[[The New York Times]]'' {{colbegin}} # (2/4/1963) ''[[The Enemy Below]]'' (1957) # (2/11/1963) ''[[The Bravados]]'' (1958) # (2/18/1963) ''[[Heaven Knows, Mr. Allison]]'' (1957) # (2/25/1963) ''[[King of the Khyber Rifles (film)|King of the Khyber Rifles]]'' (1953) # (3/4/1963) ''[[Hell and High Water (1954 film)|Hell and High Water]]'' (1954) # (3/11/1963) ''[[Prince Valiant (1954 film)|Prince Valiant]]'' (1954) # (3/18/1963) ''[[Boy on a Dolphin]]'' (1957) # (3/25/1963) ''[[From Hell to Texas]]'' (1958) # (4/1/1963) ''[[My Cousin Rachel (1952 film)|My Cousin Rachel]]'' (1952) # (4/8/1963) ''[[April Love (film)|April Love]]'' (1957) # (4/15/1963) ''[[An Affair to Remember]]'' (1957) (2 hrs, 30 min.) # (4/22/1963) ''[[The Barbarian and the Geisha]]'' (1958) # (4/29/1963) ''[[The Hunters (1958 film)|The Hunters]]'' (1958) # (5/6/1963) ''[[Harry Black (film)|Harry Black and the Tiger]]'' (1958) # (5/13/1963) ''[[The Mudlark]]'' (1950) # (5/20/1963) ''[[Mardi Gras (1958 film)|Mardi Gras]]'' (1958) {{colend}} From here through September 9, the above titles were rerun on Monday nights. None of them appeared on NBC's other film series, ''[[Saturday Night at the Movies (NBC series)|Saturday Night at the Movies]]''. The second season began below and mixed in MGM titles with those of 20th Century Fox. Like the above-listed films, these were all television premieres. The Nielsen ratings are listed next to the release year of each title. One interesting note: There is no entry below for November 25, 1963. This was the Monday after the Friday that [[John F. Kennedy|President John Kennedy]] was assassinated. Monday was the date of the state funeral, which was given all-day coverage by the networks. Understandably, NBC thus postponed broadcasting the musical ''[[Singin' in the Rain]]'' (originally slated for 11/25/63) until later in the season. {{colbegin}} # (9/16/1963) ''[[Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing (film)|Love Is a Many Splendored Thing]]'' (1955) (19.7) # (9/23/1963) ''[[David and Bathsheba (film)|David and Bathsheba]]'' (1951;2hrs, 30 min.) (17.9) # (9/30/1963) ''[[Executive Suite]]'' (1954) {First film on Network TV to receive the 'Edited for Television' tag on-screen; 4 minutes were cut} (15.4) # (10/7/1963) ''[[The Wreck of the Mary Deare (film)|The Wreck of the Mary Deare]]'' (1959) {5 minutes were cut for TV.} (15.5) # (10/14/1963) ''[[The Rains of Ranchipur]]'' (1955) {4 minutes were cut for TV.} (16.0) # (10/21/1963) ''[[The Mating Game (film)|The Mating Game]]'' (1959) (27.1) # (10/28/1963) ''[[Good Morning, Miss Dove]]'' (1955) {7 minutes were cut for TV.} (19.4) # (11/4/1963) ''[[White Feather (film)|White Feather]]'' (1955)(18.2) # (11/11/1963) ''[[Father of the Bride (1950 film)|Father of the Bride]]'' (1950) (19.3) # (11/18/1963) ''[[The Reluctant Debutante (film)|The Reluctant Debutante]]'' (1958) (16.5) # (12/2/1963) ''[[House of Numbers (1957 film)|House of Numbers]]'' (1957) (16.7) # (12/9/1963) ''[[The Wings of Eagles]]'' (1957) {10 minutes were cut for TV} (22.3) # (12/16/1963) ''[[The Lost World (1960 film)|Lost World]]'' (1960) (20.7) # (12/23/1963) ''[[The Power and the Prize]]'' (1956) (N/A) # (12/30/1963) ''[[Kiss Me Kate (film)|Kiss Me Kate]]'' (1953) {9 minutes were cut for TV} (15.9) # (1/6/1964) ''[[Seven Cities of Gold (film)|The Seven Cities of Gold]]'' (1955) (17.4) # (1/13/1964) ''[[Singin' in the Rain]]'' (1952) (19.4) # (1/20/1964) ''[[Action of the Tiger]]'' (1957) (15.8) # (1/27/1964) ''[[House of Bamboo]]'' (1955) (17.7) # (2/3/1964) ''[[Phone Call from a Stranger]]'' (1952) (18.2) # (2/10/1964) ''[[Treasure of the Golden Condor]]'' (1953) (17.4) # (2/17/1964) ''[[The Safecracker]]'' (1958) (13.4) # (2/24/1964) ''[[Prince of Players]]'' (1955) (10.6) # (3/2/1964) ''[[Underwater Warrior]]'' (1958) (16.0) # (3/9/1964) ''[[The 39 Steps (1959 film)|The 39 Steps]]'' (1960) (15.0) # (3/16/1964) ''[[The View from Pompey's Head (film)|The View from Pompey's Head]]'' (1955) (18.5) # (3/23/1964) ''[[The Racers]]'' (1955) (16.6) # (3/30/1964) ''[[The Pride of St. Louis]]'' (1952) (18.9) # (4/6/1964) ''[[The Virgin Queen (1955 film)|The Virgin Queen]]'' (1955) (14.4) # (4/13/1964) ''[[Never Let Me Go (1953 film)|Never Let Me Go]]'' (1960) (17.1) {{colend}} From here, reruns were shown for the remainder of the season until mid-September 1964, when NBC announced that it would discontinue ''Monday Night at the Movies''. Instead, a new prime-time movie night, Wednesdays, from 9 until 11 p.m. (ET), became the time slot for the network's alternative film anthology during [[1964-65 United States network television schedule|the 1964-65 season]]Adams, Val. "NBC-TV Acquires Post-1948 Movies: Buys Paramount Features for Showing in Fall." ''New York Times''. (February 12, 1964): p. 67. while Saturday nights remained a mainstay for NBC's film broadcasts. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.tvtango.com/series/nbc_monday_night_movies/episodes Episode List: NBC Monday Night Movies - TV Tango] {{Motion picture television series on NBC}} {{DEFAULTSORT:NBC Monday Movie}} [[Category:1963 American television series debuts]] [[Category:1960s American television series]] [[Category:1970s American television series]] [[Category:1980s American television series]] [[Category:1990s American television series]] [[Category:2000s American television series]] [[Category:2003 American television series endings]] [[Category:American anthology television series]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Motion picture television series]] [[Category:NBC network shows]]
